title: FirstFT: Manchin demolishes Biden's Build Back Better bill
text:
“I cannot vote to continue with this piece of legislation. I just can't. I've tried everything humanly possible. I can't get there.”

With those words Joe Manchin, the Democratic senator from West Virginia, plunged a knife into Joe Biden's economic agenda.

The declaration on Fox News Sunday ends weeks of negotiation between the White House and Manchin over Biden's signature $1.75tn social spending bill.

Manchin went on to explain his reasoning for his opposition to the bill, which includes new social investments in areas such as childcare and the fight against climate change, in a statement released after his television interview: “My concerns have only increased as the pandemic surges on, inflation rises and geopolitical uncertainty increases around the world.”

The senator's statement raises the risk the Build Back Better bill will never pass Congress and led to an angry response from moderates in the president's Democratic party.

“That is unacceptable,” said Abigail Spanberger, a Democratic Representative from Virginia.

Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, directed some of her harshest comments yet at Manchin. She said his words represented “a sudden and inexplicable reversal in his position, and a breach of his commitments to the president and the senator's colleagues in the House and Senate”.

The setback comes as the president's approval ratings have reached their highest level in months. According to the latest Realclearpolitics.com on average, 44.1 per cent of Americans approve of the job he's doing, while 50.3 per cent disapprove. That six-point gap is an improvement compared with the 12-point gap one month ago.

  • Go deeper The expansion of the Child Tax Credit was one of the sticking points for Manchin. The cheques were the US's first experiment with the type of child allowances that are commonly paid to parents in other developed nations.

Do you support Joe Biden's Build Back Better bill or are you glad it is in peril? Email me at firstft@ft.com. Here's the rest of today's news — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. Spider-Man brings hope to Hollywood Spider-Man: No Way Home, the latest instalment in the Marvel superhero franchise, took a pandemic-era record of $253m in the US at the weekend. It was the third-biggest opening in history and the largest since coronavirus struck early in 2020, according to studio estimates.

2. Former student protest leader wins Chile election Gabriel Boric has won the final round of Chile's presidential election as the Latin American country took a decisive shift to the left after several years of civil unrest. Boric secured 56 per cent of the vote in Sunday's run-off, well ahead of José Antonio Kast, his ultra-conservative rival, on 44 per cent.

3. China cuts lending rate as economic momentum falters The People's Bank of China has cut one of the country's most important lending rates in a sign that the government is pushing ahead with policy easing measures to counter a loss of economic momentum. The central bank cut the one-year loan prime rate from 3.85 per cent to 3.8 per cent.

4. Erdogan vows ‘no going back' on rate cuts The Turkish lira continued its freefall today after President Recep Tayyip Erdogan rejected warnings from business about the dangers of recent interest rate cuts and vowed there was “no going back” from his approach. The value of the Turkish lira has more than halved against the dollar since Erdogan ordered the central bank to start lowering borrowing costs in September.

5. Johnson ally resigns Lord David Frost, the UK's Brexit minister and a key ally of prime minister Boris Johnson, resigned over the weekend. Foreign secretary and potential future leader of the Conservative party, Liz Truss has been tasked with overseeing the UK's relations with the EU. How vulnerable is Boris Johnson? UK political editor George Parker assesses the outlook for the prime minister after weeks of bad news.

Coronavirus digest

  • Moderna's Covid-19 said its booster shot increases antibody levels 37-fold, compared with people who received just two doses.

  • Anthony Fauci yesterday warned of mounting “stress” on the US hospital system as new coronavirus cases tied to the highly transmissible Omicron variant start “raging” through the US.

  • European countries are tightening restrictions to reduce the spread of the Omicron variant after the Netherlands reimposed a strict nationwide lockdown.

  • UK health secretary Sajid Javid has refused to rule out tighter restrictions in England before Christmas.

  • Wealthy countries have rolled out more boosters than the total number of all doses administered in poorer nations, according to an FT analysis.

  • The divide over worker autonomy will widen in 2022 as the trend for more flexible working gathers pace, writes Pilita Clark.

  • Opinion: The imperative of smart state intervention to manage the health crisis allows Europe to embrace the social market economy, writes Martin Sandbu.

The day ahead

Italy's Zegna lists in New York The Italian luxury fashion company will go public in New York by combining with a US special purpose acquisition company for an expected enterprise value of $3.1bn.

Earnings Sportswear maker Nike is expected to report a slight rise in quarterly revenue, lifted by strong demand for its sports shoes and apparel in North America even as shipping hurdles and factory closures pinched supplies. Cheerios cereal maker's General Mills also reports earnings.

Ghislaine Maxwell trial The jury in the sex-trafficking trial of Ghislaine Maxwell may begin deliberating as early as today. Attorneys for both sides in the three-week trial will deliver their closing statements today after the defence wrapped up on Friday.

English Premier League meeting Discussions will focus on coronavirus measures as the league comes under pressure to pause football fixtures and help clubs deal with rocketing infections.

What else we're reading and listening to

The biggest market moments of 2021 From the GameStop saga to the Archegos debacle it has felt like a long year in financial markets, writes markets editor Katie Martin, as she rounds up the standout market moments of 2021.

  • Looking ahead George Steer and Chris Flood look ahead to the big questions for the markets in 2022.

‘Just in time' to ‘just in case' Companies have encountered snags in their supply chains during the pandemic as well as shipping bottlenecks, forcing a rethink of corporate strategy that includes increasing the inventory they keep on hand to entering into longer term contracts with suppliers.

Can Eric Adams revive a city losing its swagger? New York City's new mayor will take office at a time when doubts about the future of the Big Apple are spiralling. It is hard to overstate the expectations hanging on the former police officer, writes Josh Chaffin in this assessment of the task that lies ahead.

How China's global ambitions almost unseated an IMF chief Beijing has an unusual strategy to influence multilateral bodies, including the IMF and World Bank. Distinctively, China pursues its ambitions by using its unusual dual status as a developing economy and a superpower.

The dangers of politicising central banks Today, close to 90 per cent of the world's central banks are classed as independent. But as finance ministers wrestle with record debt burdens and fast-rising inflation, worries are growing that they are becoming instrumentalised by governments.

What to watch, listen to and play over the holidays

Films, TV shows, pop and classical albums, podcasts and games, our critics round up the 2021 highlights. What have you enjoyed this year? Tell us in the comments below these stories.
